#Text=Thomas Fludd
#Text=Sir Thomas Fludd ( about 1530 – 1607 ) , the son of Welsh parents , became a landowner in Kent , where he held several public offices .
#Text=His youngest son was the scientist Robert Fludd .
#Text=Origins
#Text=His father was John Fludd , the surname an English form of the Welsh Llwyd , from the village of St Martin 's in Shropshire , who married Agnes from the neighbouring village of Weston Rhyn .
#Text=Her father was Meredith Bonner , whose surname is probably an English form of the Welsh ap Ynyr .
#Text=A brother , Richard Fludd , settled in Ireland , where the surname is spelled Flood , while two of his sisters married Kent landowners .
#Text=Career
#Text=After an unknown education , around 1560 Thomas acquired Milgate House at Thurnham in Kent and became active first in local and then in national affairs .
#Text=In 1568 he secured the post of Surveyor of Crown Lands for the county of Kent and the cities of Rochester and Canterbury .
#Text=In 1572 he had a grant of arms , his shield being Vert , a chevron between three wolves heads , erased , argent , and around 1579 became a Justice of the Peace for Kent .
#Text=In 1582 he was appointed to the Exchequer as Receiver of Revenue for the counties of Kent , Surrey and Sussex .
#Text=At the request of the inhabitants , he was in 1588 put on a special commission to examine the affairs of the town of New Romney .

#Text=The next year he was knighted and appointed a paymaster to the English forces fighting in France under Lord Willoughby , a post changed after much bureaucratic in-fighting to Treasurer at War in 1597 .
#Text=In 1591 he was commissioned to supervise the renovation of Dover Harbour , being treasurer of the project in 1603 .
#Text=In 1593 he was elected MP for the borough of Maidstone and was one of the Kent gentlemen selected by the county to compound with the Commissioners for Purveyance .
#Text=In the House of Commons , he sat on the Subsidy Committee and the Committee on Kerseys .

#Text=Re-elected as Maidstone 's MP in 1597 , he was admitted to Gray 's Inn in 1601 and was elected for the third and final time to the Commons in 1601 , where he sat on a committee to consider the abolition of gavelkind . [ 1 ]
#Text=Family
#Text=He first married Elizabeth , the daughter of Philip Andrews who lived at Wellington in Somerset and his wife Elizabeth , the daughter of Henry Parker and his wife Dorothy Shelley .
#Text=She died on 25 January 1591 and was buried at Holy Cross Church in Bearsted .
#Text=He later married Barbara , widow of Sir Henry Cutts , who survived him and married William Covert .
#Text=Children are : [ 2 ]
#Text=Edward , who married Jane , daughter of Sir Michael Sands of Throwley and his wife Mary Finch , and had a daughter Mary .
#Text=He died before 1607 and Jane married Sir Thomas May .
#Text=Thomas , the eldest surviving son and heir , married Catherine , daughter of Levin Bufkin of Otham and his wife Anne Guilford .
#Text=They had three children , including Thomas his heir .
#Text=Joan married Sir Nicholas Gilborne of Charing at Bearsted on 7 April 1583 [ 3 ] and had nine children .
#Text=John , baptised at Bearsted on 10 August 1572 , [ 3 ] married Mary Purefoy and had a son Robert .
#Text=Robert Fludd baptised at Bearsted 17 Jan 1573/4
#Text=Catherine , baptised at Bearsted on 5 December 1579 , [ 3 ] married Thomas Lunsford and had seven children , including Sir Thomas Lunsford who went to Virginia .
#Text=Sarah , baptised at Bearsted on 12 March 1581 , [ 3 ] married Henry Bufkin , brother of Catherine above , and had five children .
#Text=Death and legacy
#Text=Making his will on 18 February 1607 , he died on 30 May and was buried at Bearsted .
#Text=In his will , proved on 11 June , he left small bequests to household servants , to the village church , to the poor in surrounding parishes and to the prisoners in Maidstone gaol .
#Text=Legacies also went to his sister Catherine and brother Hugh .

#Text=Most of his extensive real estate and personal effects were divided among his three surviving sons Thomas , John and Robert , with Robert also getting cash of 600 pounds ( worth at least 120,000 pounds in 2015 ) .
#Text=To his three surviving daughters , Joan , Catherine and Sarah , bequests were minor , presumably because they already had portions on marrying .
#Text=His wife Barbara kept her own goods and lands that she had brought to the marriage , with Thomas asked to let her live on at Milgate .
#Text=In addition to his London house in Old Bailey , the landholdings mentioned in his will are predominantly in Kent but extend to Surrey , Sussex and his native Shropshire . [ 4 ]
